Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Smart Antenna Laboratory Equipment

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches: The objective of this research is to meet the ever-increasing demand for reliable, secure high-bandwidth wireless communications. Bandwidth demand is being met with innovative new technologies and standards; however, the success and proliferation of these systems causes increased wireless interference, which inadvertently reduces the reliability and bandwidth of these and adjacent systems. The approach is to provide Smart Antenna Laboratory equipment that enables innovators to address issues by facilitating the design, simulation, and testing of interference-reducing, high-performance communications radios, algorithms, and antenna systems.
Intellectual Merit: As digital computational densities have followed Moore?s law, so has the complexity and performance of wireless digital communication systems. Nearly all new wireless standards use multi-antenna techniques to increase spectral efficiency and resulting system bandwidth. As the system complexity increases so does the barrier-to-entry for companies and educational institutions requiring access to the instrumentation, measurements and simulation environments required to complete robust designs and research. The establishment of the laboratory will drop this barrier-to-entry.
Broader Impacts: The Smart Antenna Laboratory at Gonzaga University leads to improved reliability for life-critical first responder communications and smart grid energy and natural resource management. It provides collaborative research and educational opportunities for faculty and students at three additional universities and one community college. Wireless technology companies are committed to collaborating with member institutions and utilizing the equipment. Native American summer science and other science, technology, engineering and math related programs expose at least 1000 K-12 students annually to Gonzaga University?s technologists and labs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The mission of the SARL is focused on two complementary goals. First it helps educate undergraduate students in RF research and development and second, it creates jobs in various sectors of the RF industry through industry/university cooperative technology research and product development.

Most of the Smart Antenna Laboratory equipment was purchased between October 2010 and January, 2011. Key services of the SARL include:

  • Local antenna measurement and Electro Magnetic Compliance (EMC) pre compliance testing
  • Access to high performance RF measurements
  • Access to skilled faculty consulting
  • Rapid prototyping
  • High performance electro magnetic modeling and microwave design tools

The facility includes:

  • 2 shielded anechoic chambers with automated 3D radiation pattern capture from Dual-Polarized reference antennas
  • 44 GHz 4 port Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) w/ time domain and 2 coherent sources for arbitrary polarization test configurations
  • 43GHz 40 MHz BW Vector Signal Analyzer (VSA) with digital demodulation.
  • MXG Signal Generator: 100kHz - 6GHz.
  • 3D Electromagnetic Simulation (HFSS) w/ cluster computing

The last piece of equipment to be purchased was supposed to be a 4x4 MIMO software defined radio platform. One such system was purchased from Lyrtech, who changed their name to Nutaq. The platform was dellivered late and the system did not need our needs. Even though they received roughly $68k from Gonzaga University, Nutaq refuses to dispense a refund for the inferior equipment. Consequently the 4x4 MIMO capability of the laboratory does not exist. Nevertheless, the SARL is accomplishing many great things.

The following publications and presentations have resulted from work in the SARL to date:

  • R. Conley, S. Schennum, T. Hillstrom, "Co-Channel Interference and Polarization Dependent Loss in Wireless SISO Communications Standards," presented at the National Wireless Research Symposium, Idaho Falls, ID, May, 2014.
  • S. Schennum, "Industry University Cooperative Research and Product Development: Creating Jobs in the Ilnand Northwest," presented at the Pacific Northwest Association of College Physics, Spokane Falls Community College, March, 2014.
  • R. Conley, S. Schennum, T. Hillstrom, "Interference Mitigatioin Using Adaptive Polarization," presented at the 2014 Wireless Innovation Forum, Schaumberg, Ill, March, 2014.
  • S. Schennum, "The Smart Antenna and Radio Lab," invited presentation at Notre Dame University's Wireless Institute, October, 2013.
  • Steven D. Schennum, Robert J. Conley. “WLAN Field Studies and Results," Conference: IEEE Antennas and Propagation Society International Symposium – APS/URSI, pp. 3352-3354, July 2011.
  • Steven D. Schennum. “Gonzaga Smart Antenna and Radio Lab,"Conference: IEEE Antennas and Propagation Society International Symposium – APS/URSI, pp. 1405-1408, July 2011
  • R. Conley, S. Schennum. “Smart Antenna Opportunities for Spectrum Resource Usage Improvements”, IEEE P802.15 Working Group for Wireless Personal Area Networks (WPANs), 8 November, 2011
